This heartwarming video captures the emotional journey of former Jehovah's Witnesses celebrating a baby's first birthday. The new mom, a first-time parent who left the faith a decade ago, hosts a joyous gathering for her child, surrounded by family members who have also broken free from the religion's strict rules.

The celebration highlights the stark contrast between their current lives and their upbringing, where birthdays were forbidden and considered pagan. As the baby experiences important milestones, the camera captures the genuine excitement and love shared by the extended family.

An aunt, now a seasoned mother, reflects on her childhood within the Jehovah's Witness community. She discusses the restrictions she faced and how she now strives to nurture her children's curiosity and ambitions. Her story provides a meaningful comparison to the life she left behind.

The video also touches on the bittersweet reality of fractured family relationships. While the gathering is filled with love and laughter, there's a noticeable absence of relatives still active in the Jehovah's Witness faith. The family discusses the pain of being shunned by their Witness relatives, who refuse to participate due to fear of punishment from their religious community.

This intimate portrayal showcases the real social impact of the Jehovah's Witnesses' ban on birthdays. It celebrates the freedom found in leaving the religion while acknowledging the ongoing struggles faced by those who break away. The video serves as a powerful testament to the resilience of these families and their determination to create new, joyful traditions despite the cost

This harrowing chapter of Witness Underground reveals the destructive mechanisms of the Jehovah’s Witness organization. Chad Rhiger, a member of Daytrip, HighTV, and Ghost Army, opens by describing the extreme social isolation used to erase the collective memory of former members. Whether individuals leave voluntarily or are disfellowshipped, the congregation enforces a system of complete emotional and social isolation. Elders—the men in charge of congregation discipline—use this form of punishment to maintain control, punishing anyone caught communicating with removed members. Such actions reinforce that all relationships within the group are conditional and devoid of genuine love. Many people refer to the Jehovah’s Witnesses as a hate group for mandating such extreme forms of isolation.

Ryan Sutter shares his struggles in this portion of the documentary. After his wife divorced him, she threatened to inform his father about Ryan’s changing beliefs unless he disclosed them himself, forcing him into an emotionally excruciating position. Additionally, Ryan reflects on the downfall of the music scene that once thrived within the religion. After leaving, Ryan’s music studio and website were handed to his brother, Reed, who rebranded them under the label Band Kids Unite. Over four years, the scene withered under this new management, further illustrating how control within the religion can extend to creative expression and community.

Eric Elvendahl provides an insider perspective on how this internal rule of law is enforced. Decisions by the elders often depend not on rule-breaking but on whether a person seems "sorry" enough. However, gossip can tip the scales toward the harshest punishment: one full year of isolation while enduring public shaming in silence during 3-5 weekly church sessions. Victims are barred from speaking, sharing meals, or making eye contact with others, effectively destroying their social and familial ties.

The clip also touches on deeply personal accounts of emotional abuse and manipulation. Cindy Elvendahl exposes an unprecedented form of sexual harassment by Jehovah’s Witness elders, recounting her experience as a teenager during a judicial meeting. This has since come out powerfully in narrative form in the short film Debutante. In this invasive and coercive process, three older men interrogated her about intimate sexual details, crossing her boundaries in ways that no Christian ministers should ever impose on a young woman. Cindy reflects on how this traumatic high-stakes experience at risk of losing her entire family and community shaped her as an adult, revealing the broader pattern of Jehovah’s Witnesses controlling women through fear and humiliation.

This clip unflinchingly exposes the intersection of elders’ sexual harassment, emotional abuse in religion, and the soul-crushing punishments inflicted on members. From coercive meetings to the conditional love that tears families apart, this segment paints a stark picture of the Jehovah’s Witnesses’ oppressive control. It also sheds light on the strength required to heal and rebuild after escaping these abusive systems.

She belted out the words her spirit had tried to hide.
Her "Prayer To No One" ricocheted off the walls to a riveted crowd.

They wanted an encore.
She knew a private punishment wasn’t going to be enough.
She went back for more.

Three short interviews capture the diverse experiences of individuals who found the courage to question their upbringing in this "Apocalyptic cult" and, in doing so, discovered the strength to forge their own paths.

They dive into how they feel about this group looking back into their strange past.

Cognitive dissonance, conflict caused by religion, inner feelings as a witness, cultural norms within the cult, mis-education, becoming open-minded, disconnection with organized religion, different way to believe in god, atheism, enjoying life now rather than waiting on a higher power, reconnecting with grandparents and other family that were disconnected from because of this religions intolerance of non-members. Join us as we explore the transformative power of art, music, therapy, movement, and meditation in coping while inside and healing after leaving a cult. Description:
In this compelling episode, we sit down with Gina Brown, Christopher of the band Scifidelic and Writer Brie Yarbrough in discussion with Scott Homan, Director of the award winning and eye-opening documentary "Witness Underground," which sheds light on artists who escaped a cult.

Together, we delve deep into their unique perspectives on shunning, drawing from their diverse experiences. We explore the profound impact of music, art, therapy, movement, and meditation as coping mechanisms during their time in the cult and as tools for healing after leaving.

Prepare to be inspired as we explore their creative endeavors, from dance and acting to crafting a new Streaming Series pitch and building on a successful TikTok channel. We'll also uncover the intriguing story behind their decades-long music project called Scifidelic, featuring a band member known as Caustic, who was once a high-ranking member at the world headquarters of the Jehovah's Witnesses. Discover how their music directly addresses the themes of faith and exiting from it.

Our guest, Gina, shares details about her exciting project—a series about the complexities of love, where an unlikely couple comes together amidst their vastly different worlds. Having experienced trauma within the Jehovah's Witness community, Gina incorporates her personal journey into the script, exploring the challenges of same-sex relationships and the harmful influence of the faith. We'll also touch upon the harrowing experiences of her sister-in-law, who faced life-threatening complications during childbirth due to the cult's ban on blood transfusions.

Additionally, we discuss Brie's upcoming book, which inspired her escape from the cult and provided solace and courage during her challenging journey. 

Together, we explore strategies for overcoming triggers, dealing with attachment, and addressing past baggage. Moreover, we delve into the diverse interpretations of the cult's teachings regarding the end of the world and the impact it had on our guests' lives.

Join us for this thought-provoking conversation that unveils the power of art, resilience, and self-discovery. Get ready to expand your consciousness and embark on a journey of inspiration and empowerment.
